FacilityName: City of Tampa - Howard F. Curren AWTP

1.    Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:



The City of Tampa's Howard F. Curren Advance Wastewater Treatment (HFC AWTP) uses both chlorine and sulfur dioxide as part of the wastewater treatment process.  The stored volume of these chemicals is above the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) threshold for requiring the establishment and submittal of a risk management plan.  This plan along with other safety precautions is intended to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to the personal health of maintenance and operation workers, as well as co-workers, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is the policy of the HFC AWTP to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  The HFC AWTP uses several safety measures regarding the storage, handling and use of these chemicals including devices inherent in the design of the plant facilities, safe handling procedures, and extensive training of personnel.

The HFC AWTP's accidental release prevention program involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices.  The HFC AWTP adheres to all applicable procedures of the USEPA Prevention Program.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.



2.    The stationary source and regulated substances handled.



-    The regulated substances handled at this facility are chlorine and sulfur dioxide.



-    The primary purpose of this facility is to treat the wastewater from the City of Tampa Service Area. Both chlorine and sulfur dioxide are received in 90-ton rail cars and stored at either the chlorine unloading station or the sulfur dioxide unloading station.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel, and authorized contractors.



-    The maximum amount of chlorine that can be stored at

this plant is 270,000 pounds (lbs). However, the average daily amount is 115,000 pounds. The maximum amount of sulfur dioxide that can be stored at this plant is 270,000 pounds. However, the average daily amount is 115,000 pounds.



3.    The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario.

Worst-Case Release Scenario:

-    Worst-Case Scenario - The USEPA states that "the owner shall assume the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a gas over 10 minutes."  At the HFC AWTP, this would be the failure of the largest sulfur dioxide storage vessel.  When filled to the greatest amount allowed, the scenario would release 180,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide.  



-    Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed to determine the distance at which the toxic endpoint (3 parts per million) is reached.  The maximum centerline downwind distance was determined to be 15.0 miles using USEPA's Guidance for Waste Water Treatment Plants Reference Tables and Equations.  The inputs and assumptions used to determine the end point were as follows:  Quantity Released 180,000 lbs, Release Rate = 18000 lbs/minute, Wind Speed = 1.5 m/s, Topography = Urban, Atmospheric Stability Class = F, No mitigation was considered



-    The residential population within the 15-mile radius defined above is 1,021,061 people.  However, only the population within an elliptical plume extending downwind of the release point is potentially affected.  The plum area is approximately 6% of the area of the full circle.  The data source used for this estimate was the 2010 US Census.



Alternative Release Scenario: 

-    Alternative Scenario - The USEPA states that the scenario shall be "more likely to occur than the worst-case release and that it will reach an endpoint off-site".  The release of sulfur dioxide or chlorine from a ruptured pipe (1" hole) would most accurately represe

nt an alternative release scenario.  

?X    Chlorine Alternate Release Scenario - Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed to determine the distance at which the endpoint is reached.  The maximum centerline downwind distance was determined to be 0.7 miles using USEPA's Guidance for Waste Water Treatment Plants Reference Tables and Equations.  The inputs and assumptions used to determine the end point were as follows:  Quantity Released 25,000 lbs, Release Rate = 2,500 lbs/minute, Wind Speed = 3 m/s, Topography = Urban, Atmospheric Stability Class = D, Mitigation systems = The chlorine system has an excess flow valve that will shut off the flow to the system when the flow reaches 15,000 pounds per hour (lbs/hr).  The residential population within the 0.7 mile radius is 71.  The area immediately surrounding the HFC AWTP is industrial.  The data source used for this estimate was the 2010 US Census data.  

?X    Sulfur Dioxide Alternate Release Scenario - Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed to determine the distance at which the endpoint is reached.  The maximum centerline downwind distance was determined to be 0.6 miles using USEPA's Guidance for Waste Water Treatment Plants Reference Tables and Equations.  The inputs and assumptions used to determine the end point were as follows:  Quantity Released 16,000 lbs, Release Rate = 1,600 lbs/minute, Wind Speed = 3 m/s, Topography = Urban, Atmospheric Stability Class = D, Mitigation systems = sulfur dioxide has an excess flow valve that will shut off the flow to the system when the flow reaches 15,000 pounds per hour (lbs/hr).  The residential population within the 0.6 mile radius is 0.  The area immediately surrounding the HFC AWTP is industrial.  The data source used for this estimate was the 2010 US Census data.  



4.     The general accidental release prevention program and the specific prevention steps. 

The HFC AWTP's general accidental release prevention program complies with the USEPA's Accidental Release

Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.

The HFC AWTP's general accidental release prevention program contains four parts: designing for safety, maintaining safe operations, operating safely, and auditing our operations.



Designing for safety:

-    Rail car construction meets federal guideline 49CFR179.102

-    Excessive-flow check valve prevents rapid release of rail car contents

-    Redundant or backup safety systems are part of design

-    Remote sensing device to detect leaks

-    Valves and equipment are tagged and numbered



Maintaining safe operations:

-    Safety reviews for all changes

-    Maintenance personal trained on the job by standards set by the Chlorine Institute

-    Preventative maintenance program conducted by qualified technicians

-    Equipment checked on a routine schedule

-    Frequent walk-through inspections by maintenance personnel 



Operating safely:

-    Written operating procedures and operational standards based on hazard analysis

-    Established shut-down procedures

-    Standby generator available for backup power

-    Leak sensors monitored in control room

-    Operators present during loading and unloading of rail cars



Auditing our operations:

-    Critical equipment/instrumentation tested and inspected weekly to assure proper operation

-    Pre-startup safety reviews on new or modified equipment 

-    Process hazard analysis conducted regularly 

-    Design changes reviewed for proper design 

-    Investigation and follow-up of all accidents and incidents



5.     Five-year accident history.

The HFC AWTP had a reportable incident on 9/19/2011.  The individual was exposed to chlorine gas while disconnecting the railcar.  The incident was investigated and several action items were generated that included requirement of additional personal protection equipment and additional training.



6.     The emergency response program.

The HFC AWTP's emergency response program is based upon training and preparation.

-    Written plant site Emergenc

y Preparedness Plan

-    On-site inspection of facility by Hazmat Team

-    Emergency response equipment including self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) and chemical suits located on site

-    All chlorine and sulfur dioxide operators trained in emergency response and emergency plant shut-down procedures

-    Chlorine and sulfur dioxide unloading site and procedures inspected by manufacturer's Technical Support Specialist

-    Member of District VIII Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC)

The HFC AWTP is a first responder by notification only.  If a release were to occur, the facility would call 911, which would contact Tampa Fire Rescue, Office of Emergency Management, and the LEPC.  The HFC AWTP also has a facility-wide alarm and response network monitored by a SCADA computer system.  The facility site alarm would activate to warn on-site personnel, and emergency remote shut-down procedures in place would be activated.  If the release were to have the potential to affect the general public, the Office of Emergency Management would sound an alarm for the area.  We have discussed this program with the District VIII Local Emergency Planning Committee and Tampa Fire Rescue. The facility would also call the Florida State Warning Point at 1-800-320-0519.





7.     Planned changes to improve safety.

The Tampa Port Authority has begun installation of an area wide chemical release monitoring and audible alarm system.  One of the monitoring points will be located on our site near the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems and operate independently of our monitoring system.  The area wide monitoring system will be interconnected to help communicate emergency situations to neighboring properties.  The alarm will be audible for several miles and pre-defined instructions will be announced over the siren systems that are specific to the event that triggered the alarm.  The system is projected to be completed by early 2015.
